entry.title: People Analytics ‚Äì Reporting | A Real Consultant Story on Cleaning Duplicate Data
entry.content:
Working with ERP systems like SAP, Oracle, or Workday often comes with one universal pain‚Äîreporting.

The challenge isn‚Äôt just creating a report. That part is usually straightforward‚Äîdrag and drop fields, define filters, and hit run. But what happens after that? You export the report to Excel‚Ä¶ and the real work begins.

Suddenly you‚Äôre cleaning up duplicate rows, fixing totals, applying VLOOKUPs, and trying to present something trustworthy for leadership. We‚Äôve all been there.

Recently, my colleague Nidhi and I faced exactly this while building a Compensation Report in SAP SuccessFactors People Analytics (Canvas Reporting). Our goal was clear: build something clean, accurate, and usable‚Äîwithout needing post-export manual work.

Here‚Äôs how we got there.

The Challenge ‚Äì Duplicate Rows & Messy Output

- Multiple rows per employee
- Manual cleanup
- Leadership fatigue

This wasn‚Äôt just a technical nuisance‚Äîit was undermining trust in the output, and by extension, in the team creating it.

Our Step-by-Step Approach to Fix It

1. Plan Before You Click

We started by clearly defining what the report needed to deliver. For us, that meant:
- Base compensation details (like pay component and amount)
- Personal identifiers (like employee ID, first and last name)
- Relevant job or salary structure data

We intentionally avoided adding too many fields or overly complex joins.

2. Create the Report in Canvas

We used Canvas Reporting inside SAP SuccessFactors. This format gave us flexibility to:
- Pull from multiple domains
- Manage data relationships visually
- Use Design View to control logic and apply smart formatting

 

 

 

 

 

Click on Edit query

 

Then select new query so that you can build your query through (pivot table)

 

3. Build the Query Carefully

With the design structure in place, we built the query with extra care:
- Chose only the necessary fields
- Linked tables via unique identifiers like Employee ID
- Avoided one-to-many or many-to-many joins

 

Note: Choose the right base object as instructed by the client requirement, expected to select the highest base object, as an instance where we choose ‚ÄúCompensation‚Äù instead of salary information similar if you are creating report for Time account balance you can choose ‚ÄúTime account‚Äù and it is Leave transaction report choose ‚ÄúEmployee time‚Äù and so on.

 

 

Click on Save and then Return.

 

You will be dragged to the below screen, click Show Design View.

 

In SAP SuccessFactors reports, measures represent quantifiable data that is aggregated or analyzed, while dimensions provide the context or categories for the measures

 

 

4. Clean Up Duplicates with Pivot Logic

Inside Design View, we used Pivot Functions to eliminate unwanted duplicates:
- Grouped records and showed only the first instance of each pay component
- Applied logic to exclude blank or null values
- Used display rules for one row per employee

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

5. Review, Test, and Refine

Once built, we tested the report thoroughly:
- Ran live samples to spot inconsistencies
- Shared it with colleagues for review
- Adjusted logic to ensure accuracy and trust

 

 

 

What We Learned

Sometimes, the small operational problems‚Äîlike duplicate rows in a report‚Äîcan have a bigger business impact than the complex projects we work on.

Thanks to Nidhi for her collaboration, patience, and meticulousness throughout the process. This was a simple challenge, but solving it meant we could finally offer something useful to leadership‚Äîwithout requiring another manual step.

Why This Matters (Beyond SAP)

Whether you‚Äôre using SAP, Oracle OTBI, or Workday‚Äîthis story will probably feel familiar.

You want reports that:
- Are clean and easy to read
- Don‚Äôt require manual work after download
- Can be trusted immediately by decision-makers

We‚Äôre sharing our experience to help others avoid the same struggle.

Final Thoughts

ERP tools are powerful‚Äîbut clean reporting takes care, collaboration, and intent.

If you‚Äôre a fellow consultant, report builder, or HR tech practitioner: keep solving the small things. Sometimes, they‚Äôre what matter the most.

Let‚Äôs keep learning‚Äîand building‚Äîtogether.

entry.title: SAP Analytics Business Intelligence Statement of Direction ‚Äì July 2025 update
entry.content:
The SAP Analytics Business Intelligence Statement of Direction provides guidance to our SAP BusinessObjects customers on the product directions for SAP analytics solutions. We published a new version this month with some important updates which can be found here.

 

SAP Business Data Cloud

SAP Business Data Cloud delivers deep integration of Data Management, Analytics and Planning augmented by AI in one native cloud solution. This allows to move from insight to action, brings analytics closer to the point of decision and provides trusted insights from customers‚Äô most valuable data.

SAP Analytics Cloud, as a key component of SAP Business Data Cloud, provides trustworthy analytics for any user from any context and remains the recommended option for all new planning and analytics projects. The closed loop from insight to action allows customers to identify challenges, analyze options and execute decisions from one place.

Our knowledge of customer data and integration to business process enable customers to rapidly deploy analytics to address their most important business problems.

 

SAP BusinessObjects BI

With more than 30 years of innovations, SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence platform (SAP BusinessObjects BI) equips thousands of companies which reliably manage enterprise reporting use cases at scale. Our revised maintenance strategy guarantees Mainstream Maintenance until at least end of 2031 which secures your investments on the long run, whether you want to deploy on premise or in a private cloud.

New maintenance strategy

Starting with BI 4.3, Mainstream Maintenance is now followed by Customer Specific Maintenance during which we deliver fixes for high and very high security issues (CVSS >= 7) during the first year. We are extending BI 4.3 Mainstream Maintenance until end of 2026 so that security fixes are guaranteed until end of 2027 as previously committed.

With SAP BusinessObjects BI 2025, we adopt a revised delivery cycle which addresses the need for more stability while keeping regular updates: we are moving away from support packages delivered every year and supported only during 18 months to minor releases delivered every 2 years, benefiting from 3 years of Mainstream Maintenance, followed Customer Specific Maintenance including 1 year of security fixes.

We already plan for a next release, BI 2027, which should be available in Q1 2027, followed by another one 2 years later, and we will revisit our roadmap on a regular basis.

SAP BusinessObjects BI 2025 and beyond

SAP BusinessObjects BI 2025 is available since March 2025. This new version illustrates our strategy going forward: continue the modernization started in version 4.3 and streamline the suite by focusing on the core components while providing alternatives for unsupported ones.

Our strategy is based on 3 pillars: reach more business users, increase power users‚Äô productivity and reduce total cost of ownership. To maximize the value for our customers, we will focus ongoing investments on the most-widely adopted SAP BusinessObjects BI solutions: SAP BusinessObjects Web Intelligence, single source .unx universes, SAP Crystal Reports, and the SAP BusinessObjects BI platform.

 SAP Analysis for Microsoft Office and SAP Lumira Designer will be maintained and supported, but no new feature will be delivered.

We will provide alternatives

With SAP BusinessObjects BI 2025, we do not deliver anymore SAP Lumira Discovery, SAP Crystal Reports for Enterprise, SAP BusinessObjects Universe Design Tool and .unv universes, multi-source universes and associated connectivity, SAP BusinessObjects Analysis edition for OLAP, SAP BusinessObjects Live Office and SAP BusinessObjects Mobile, but we are recommending alternatives for all use cases.

We will stop supporting AIX and Solaris after version 4.3 and will focus on Windows and Linux.

 

Move your analytics to the cloud

For companies willing to move analytics workloads to the cloud, we offer 2 complementary options: SAP BusinessObjects BI operated in a private cloud and SAP Business Data Cloud.

SAP BusinessObjects, private cloud edition is an opportunity to shift from a maintenance contract to a subscription model while leveraging your existing investments in SAP BusinessObjects BI solutions.

SAP Business Data Cloud is recommended for new applications, use cases and users, and along with our partner community, we are committed to support every customer through this journey with tools and programs.

 

Want to learn more?

Enjoy right now the full SAP Analytics Business Intelligence Statement of Direction.

entry.title: A Beginners guide to SAP BDC
entry.content:
Many developers have contacted me in message box asking how to start with learning SAP BDC.

SAP Has provided many learning paths for same which are available on the Learning hub, but, what about people who don‚Äôt have access to learning hub or someone who is still working in legacy technologies.

Sharing these learning links hoping that this will help atleast a few people who trying to learn SAP BDC.

 

Core Components of SAP BDC system

Layer

Description

Source Systems

Includes SAP S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, and external systems. Data is bundled into entities like tables and views for replication.

Foundation Services

Harmonizes and transforms raw data into Data Products. These are stored in a hyperscaler environment (SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake files).

SAP Datasphere

Acts as the semantic layer. Defines data models, manages access control, and supports both prebuilt and custom analytical scenarios.

SAP Databricks

Embedded AI/ML engine for advanced analytics. Enables pro-code engineering and machine learning extensions.

SAP Analytics Cloud

Provides visualization, planning, and ad-hoc analysis capabilities. Powers dashboards and intelligent applications.

BDC Cockpit

Central hub for managing Data Products, Intelligent Applications, and data sharing workflows.

 

You must learn SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics cloud to be ready for SAP BDC.

 

You may use below link to learn more about SAP Datasphere.

Get Started with Your Trial in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials

This mission is the ideal starting point for newcomers to start using SAP Datasphere, get their trial account, and learn the fundamentals for modelling their data in SAP Datasphere.

This training will cover below activities.

  1. Get to Know the SAP Datasphere Interface | SAP Tutorials : talks about how to navigate the user interface of SAP Datasphere and what the home screen controls can do for you
  2. Add Users and Assign Roles in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to add users into your SAP Datasphere tenant, how to assign roles to users, How to edit users in bulk
  3. Create and Monitor a Space in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to create a Space and how to manage and monitor your Space
  4. Create an Entity Relationship Model in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about overview of E/R Models, how to create an E/R Model, how to associate data columns and how to finalise an E/R Model and deploy
  5. Create a Graphical View in SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : talks about graphical views, how to create them, how to rename and restore columns in Graphical view and their deployment
  6. Define Measures and Add Business Information to a View | SAP Tutorials talks about what is semantic information, how to define measures, how to add business information, how to change business names of measures and attributes, how to change the semantic type of measures and attributes and how to preview your modelled dataset
  7. Generate Time Table and Dimensions | SAP Tutorials talks about how to create time tables and dimensions and how to associate the time dimensions with your data
  8. Upload Flat Files and Wrangle Your Data | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to upload flat files in the Data Builder of SAP Datasphere, how to make the best of the Data Builder capabilities during a file upload process and how to transform the data for data consistency and integrity
  9. Replicate Data into SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to check the type of data access, how to create a real time data replication and how to schedule the data replication
  10. Integrate and Monitor Data with SAP Datasphere | SAP Tutorials : Talks about how to access the Data Integration Monitor, how to use the Data Integration Monitor dashboard and the types of monitoring you can do with the Data Integration Monitor

 

 

You can use below links to know more about SAP Analytics cloud.

  1. Exploring SAP Analytics Cloud
  2. Create a Live Data Connection in SAP Analytics Cloud | SAP Tutorials
  3. Create Live Data Model and a Story | SAP Tutorials
  4. Develop and Consume Queries on SAP Analytics Cloud | SAP Tutorials

SAP has basic trial versions for both SAP Datasphere and SAC where you may get some hands on knowledge to perform few activities.

Get started with Basic Trial | SAP Tutorials

 

Once you have a good understanding of SAP Datasphere and SAC, you can start going through SAP BDC learning paths.

Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud

 

You may also go through below blogs

SAP BDC for Dummies - SAP Community

SAP BDC Key Features - SAP Community

Deep Dive into SAP BDC Data products - SAP Community

 

Happy Learning!

 

Swati Gawade-Shingade.

Cognizant technology Solutions.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in June
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in June

Another month with a great new release delivery ‚ú®
Learn more in my short top features video in June 2025 on YouTube üì∫
In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs.

 

 

My top features in June

 

SQL and Script Views as Source Objects for Your Replication Flows

You can create a replication flow with an SQL view or a script view as a source. Supported connections are SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA On-premise and SAP Datasphere. Initial only loads are currently supported, and you must define a primary key for your view to allow the deployment. 
‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

Python Version 3.11 available for Data Flows

The Data Flow script operator enables the Python version 3.11 for your data flows. When creating a data flow or modifying an existing one, you can now choose the new Python Version 3.11. Please note that Python 3.9 will reach its end-of-life soon, hence we recommend upgrading your data flows to 3.11 as the maintenance for 3.9 ends in October 2025. 
‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

New Data Types Supported for Local Tables (File)

We now support additional data types for local tables in the file space on the object store. You can now select the additional data types: DateTime, hana.BINARY and hana.TINYINT. 
‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

Object Store API calls

We separated API request calls from the compute in the flexible tenant configuration. That means you can now specify the number of API requests separately when configuring object storage. With the new option, you can define the expected number of API calls per month, giving you more control and accuracy in estimating your object storage needs. 
‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

 

My favorite blog in June

There is an excellent blog I want you to be aware of. My friend and co-author of multiple books @FrankRiesner wrote this blog about SAP BW PCE and explains what it is, and also what it is not.
‚û°Ô∏è  Enjoy your read: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/what-exactly-is-sap-bw-pce-and-what-it-is-not/ba-p/14127149

entry.title: Shaping the Future of SAP data and analytics solutions
entry.content:
Our data and analytics solutions can help you quickly integrate, model, manage, and use data from anywhere. SAP Business Data Cloud is a fully managed SaaS solution that unifies and governs all SAP data and seamlessly connects with third-party data‚Äîgiving line-of-business leaders context to make even more impactful decisions.

And for developers, SAP HANA Cloud is our leading tool for developing intelligent data applications and extending applications. Finally, Master Data Governance helps you pull together master data and manage it centrally using a master data management layer.

 

With the new projects of the SAP Customer Engagement Initiative we offer you the opportunity to influence SAP‚Äôs latest innovations when directly working with our developers to define and shape future product directions.

Register until July 25 and take advantage of this opportunity!

 

Enhancing the SAP HANA Cloud and SAP Build Code Experience

SAP HANA Database Migration to SAP HANA Cloud (XSC,XSA,CAP)

The Gen AI Assistant in SAP HANA Cloud

Uplift modelling and causality analysis for SAP Analytics  Cloud

If you are also interested in other CEI projects that are currently open for registration, see here the full list.

Thank you in advance for your participation!

entry.title: Automating Flat File Loads in SAP Datasphere Using Generic SFTP Connections
entry.content:
With Datasphere release 2025.11, SAP introduced a powerful new feature: the Generic SFTP Connection. This enhancement significantly simplifies and automates the process of loading flat files into Datasphere.
Traditionally, users had to manually upload each flat file, which was cumbersome especially when dealing with multiple files. Now, with Generic SFTP, the process can be fully automated using scripting (e.g., Python), resulting in faster and more efficient bulk data ingestion.

This blog walks you through a basic method to leverage the Generic SFTP connection as a source object in a Data Flow. File formats currently supported include:JSON, JSONL, CSV, XLS, XLSX, ORC, and PARQUET.

Key Benefits

  • Automates repetitive flat file loads
  • Supports bulk data ingestion
  • Can be orchestrated using SAP Integration Suite or custom scripts (e.g., Python)

Prerequisites

  1. Valid Generic SFTP Connection
  2. Source File Availability

Steps to Load Data from Generic SFTP

First, you need to create a Data Flow to handle how the data will be ingested when transferred to generic SFTP

  • Go to the "Sources" tab in the Data Builder. Expand the "Connections" folder, navigate to the SFTP connection, and select the folder containing the source file.

 

  • Drag and drop the file onto the canvas.
  • (Optional) Click "Modify" to edit columns if needed. You can rename, remove, or change data types.

  • Click the source node and choose "Add Table" to create a new target table.
  • Click "Create and Deploy Table".
  • Choose the appropriate load Mode:
    • Append ‚Äì Add new records to existing data
    • Truncate ‚Äì Clear existing data before loading
    • Delete ‚Äì Remove existing records based on matching keys before loading
  • Run the Data Flow to load data into the target table.

Example Use Case: Automating Product Image Integration

Our organization leveraged the Generic SFTP Connections feature in SAP Datasphere to automate the integration of product image data into Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC). Here's how the solution was implemented:

  • A third-party system generates a flat file containing Product IDs and corresponding image URLs every time a new product is added.
  • For the initial load, we used a Python script to transfer this file to the SFTP server. A Dataflow configured in Append mode then loaded the file into a target table in Datasphere.
  • To incorporate the image URLs into the data model, we extended the Product Master Data dimension in Datasphere by adding a new attribute for the image URL. The semantic type of this attribute was set to "Image URL".
  • This enhancement allowed seamless integration into existing SAC dashboards, enabling dynamic display of product images.
  • For ongoing daily updates, we scheduled the Dataflow to run automatically. SAP Integration Suite transfers the updated file to the same SFTP folder each day, using a consistent file name to support full automation.

End result

# Generic script to transfer file to SFTP Server
# Be sure to change the source file and destination folder name
import paramiko
import os
# === SFTP connection details ===
hostname = <enter SFTP host> 
port = 22  # Usually 22 for SFTP
username = <enter user name> 
password = <Enter password> 
# === Local file and remote folder ===
local_file_path = < Source File name with Path> 
remote_folder_path = <Target Destination>    # No filename, just the folder

def upload_file_sftp():
   try:
       # Extract just the filename
       filename = os.path.basename(local_file_path)
       remote_file_path = os.path.join(remote_folder_path, filename).replace('\\', '/')

       # Connect to SFTP
       transport = paramiko.Transport((hostname, port))
       transport.banner_timeout = 10  # Prevent timeout errors
       transport.connect(username=username, password=password)

       sftp = paramiko.SFTPClient.from_transport(transport)

       # Upload the file
       print(f"Uploading {local_file_path} to {remote_file_path}")
       sftp.put(local_file_path, remote_file_path)
       print("Upload successful.")
       sftp.close()
   transport.close()

   except Exception as e:
       print(f"Error occurred: {e}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
   upload_file_sftp()

Conclusion

This new feature drastically streamlined data ingestion pipelines and reduced manual effort for teams managing frequent flat file loads. By combining Datasphere‚Äôs Generic SFTP connections with automation scripts, organizations can achieve fully managed and scalable data pipelines

entry.title: SAP BDC Ecosystem
entry.content:
By now you may have got a good understanding of SAP BDC components from my earlier blogs.

Now let's try to see how it all fits together.

 

 

At the first level we start with the data repository source. It may be an SAP system (like SAP S/4, Success Factor, SAP BW etc. )  or any non-SAP system.

Customers struggle a lot in heterogeneous system where data is stored in multiple different data storage systems. This data is vital for reporting.

 

For the data-driven modern organisations, having convenient access to all the necessary data in a specific and centralised location is important. Easy, convenient access ensures that data resources are always available at a moment‚Äôs notice, easing the process for you and allowing you to conduct all operations. 

 

With SAP BDC, various in-built SAP provided connectors available which we can use to connect to SAP as well as non-SAP systems and integrate them as a source of information i.e. transactional & master data.

SAP BDC system resides in SAP BTP platform similar to SAP Datasphere tenant sub-accounts currently. 

You will have a separate SAP Datasphere instance inside your SAP BDC environment.

SAP Datasphere is the evolution of the SAP data warehouse(earlier SAP BW) solution in the cloud, combining capabilities from SAP Data Warehouse Cloud with its agile enterprise data warehouse, self-service data modelling and SAP Data Intelligence Cloud with its data orchestration, lineage, quality, among other capabilities.

In data integration projects, a lot of time is spent trying to recreate context that has been lost during data replication, especially when getting data from the database layer belonging to heterogeneous storage systems.

With SAP BDC, customers will be able to bring all the structured and non-structured data under single umbrella in business data fabric.

This simplifies complex data landscapes and delivers meaningful data to every data consumer, be it Data architect, business user or a decision maker ‚Äì it takes the benefits and value further by keeping the business logic and application context from data intact.

For each of the source systems, SAP has provided ready-to-use data products which can be found in SAP BDC Cockpit.

To use out-of-the-box Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud with third-party data, first browse the available Data Products in the SAP Business Data Cloud Cockpit. Then select and install the one that best meets your requirements before proceeding with integration.

 

 

 

 SAP BDC system eliminates the need to recreate all the business context lost from extracting data - giving business stakeholders and data consumers the ability to accelerate their decision-making with trust and confidence, knowing they always have the complete picture of their data regardless of where it is stored or how it was designed.

 

SAP Data products are combination of curated views & tables, metadata, access control, inbound and outbound interfaces, load capabilities, data lineage etc. which are used by semantic layer in SAP Datasphere by consumption ready data models which can be then used for internal data manipulation and transformation.

 

This data can then be used for

  1. Reporting by SAP Analytics cloud through live data, dashboards and stories
  2. AI/ML capabilities by Databricks for powerful compute and advance analytics
  3. Visualization by intelligent apps for business users to interact with real-time insights securely and intuitively

 

SAP BDC replicates source data into Datasphere object store once; downstream consumers access it from there.

With use of delta Sharing , Databricks gets real-time access to data without duplication saving storage space and associated costs.

 

 

 

All in all, SAP BDC is built upon a robust stack of integrated components, each playing a vital role in its functionality.

  • SAP BDC combines SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and their capabilities into one fully managed SaaS solution for all data and analytics needs.
  • It seamlessly integrates mission-critical SAP data with third-party sources‚Äîwithout losing business context or requiring constant extraction.
  • SAP transforms and harmonizes business data within a hyperscaler environment, ensuring high-quality, ready-to-use data across the board.
  • Prebuilt SAP Business Data Cloud Intelligent Applications deliver instant, AI-powered business insights with minimal setup, accelerating decision-making and innovation.

 

Ultimately, SAP BDC helps organizations:

  • Streamline operations with advanced data pipelines
  • Accelerate innovation through AI and predictive analytics
  • Improve agility by enabling teams to respond to change quickly
  • Drive business growth by turning data into a competitive advantage

 

Happy Learning!

 

Swati Gawade-Shingade.

Cognizant technology Solutions.

You may also go through below blogs

SAP BDC for Dummies - SAP Community

SAP BDC Key Features - SAP Community

Deep Dive into SAP BDC Data products - SAP Community

entry.title: Data Lineage ‚Äì Do it Yourself with SAP HANA and SAC
entry.content:
Management Summary 

  1. Data lineage is crucial for understanding the origin and usage of data ‚Äì a central requirement for data governance, data quality, and efficient data management. 
  2. With SAP HANA and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), a cost-effective and quickly implementable solution for data lineage can be realized, as both products are already included in the licensing of many companies. 
  3. The Object Dependencies in SAP HANA provide comprehensive information about dependencies between tables, views, and other objects, which can be directly read in SAC via a live connection. 
  4. Thanks to the R-integration in SAC (e.g., with the R package "collapsibleTree"), an interactive tree representation is created, offering business users an intuitive and transparent overview of data flows and relationships. 
  5. This approach enables an automated, real-time view of data origin, improves the maintainability of reports and data models, and lays the foundation for reliable and data governance-compliant analytics applications.

Introduction

In modern data warehouse architectures, data lineage plays an increasingly important role. Companies want to trace where data comes from, how it is transformed, and in which reports it is ultimately used. Transparent data origin significantly contributes to data quality and governance. It also creates data understanding and facilitates the implementation of reporting requirements, especially in self-service environments.

Companies with an SAP tech stack are often familiar with the principle of data lineage from SAP BW, where data flows can be visualized via the data flow object. However, in modern system landscapes where SAP BW is combined with SAP HANA ‚Äì for example, through hybrid architectures with native HANA views and BW objects ‚Äì this visualization reaches its limits. In native HANA development, such visualization options are even completely missing.

Although established tools like Collibra or D-QUANTUM offer comprehensive lineage functions, they require additional licenses, implementation effort and a structuring of organizational process to get the full potential out of the tools. For many use cases ‚Äì such as error analysis or the development of new requirements ‚Äì a lighter solution is sufficient.

Therefore, we looked for a lean and quickly implementable alternative that supports development in complex system landscapes. Our goal: to automatically identify and visualize the dependencies of SAP HANA objects ‚Äì without additional third-party tools.

In this blog post, we show how to implement a cost-effective and quick visualization of data lineage using SAP HANA Object Dependencies and a live connection to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC). A special highlight: Through the integration of R in SAC (including the R package "collapsibleTree"), data origin is visualized in an interactive tree structure in an SAC story.

 

Motivation: Why Data Lineage?

The requirements for transparency, traceability, and efficiency in data architectures are increasing ‚Äì especially in regulated and data-driven companies. Data lineage makes a decisive contribution here:

  • Transparency: Knowing the origin and usage of data creates trust and better decision-making foundations.
  • Data understanding: A clear overview of data flows facilitates both operation and the implementation of reporting and analysis requirements.
  • Maintainability: Changes in the data model can be better assessed if the affected downstream objects are known.
  • Compliance: Regulations like GDPR require traceable documentation of data processing.

Many companies already have some form of data lineage ‚Äì but usually maintained manually by data engineers in PowerPoint, Excel, or Word. The result: high maintenance effort, outdated documentation, and lack of up-to-date information in ongoing operations.

Our solution is based on existing SAP HANA and SAC licenses and combines automated determination of data flows with an interactive representation through R integration. This creates a maintainable, always up-to-date, and interactive overview of data flows ‚Äì without additional tools or costs.

 

Technical Background: SAP HANA Object Dependencies

SAP HANA provides Object Dependencies in the form of metadata tables and views, where relationships between different objects are stored. Here you can find information about which objects depend on and are linked to each other. A brief overview:

  • Data source: The Objects Dependencies View can be found in the HANA schema SYS under the name OBJECT_DEPENDENCIES.
  • Object types: Tables, views, stored procedures, etc.
  • Dependencies: Relationships between objects, e.g., which tables or views are used for an SAC report.
  • Usage: Supports impact and lineage analyses directly at the database level.

Through a live connection in SAP Analytics Cloud, this information can be queried and visualized in real-time.

Figure 1: Extract from the Object Dependencies | SELECT TOP 1000 * FROM SYS.OBJECT_DEPENDENCIES.

Implementation in SAP Analytics Cloud

To implement the data lineage solution in SAC, two prerequisites must be met:

  • Live connection to SAP HANA: With the HANA live connection the necessary metadata is read from HANA in real time to ensure that it is up to date. This live connection must be created.
  • R server configuration: An R package is used for visualization. The use of R must be activated in SAC.

The necessary steps in order to create the lineage visualization can be summarized as follows:

  • Data preparation in SAP HANA
    • Preparation of metadata: For optimal visualization, the metadata is prepared, e.g., filtering object types, enriching descriptions.
    • Provision as a calculation view: The data is prepared as a calculation view as a basis for the SAC story.
  • Establishing a live connection to HANA
    • Configure live connection: Set up the HANA connection in SAC under Connections ‚Üí Live Data Connection.
    • Create data model in SAC: Reference the live data model to the created view/table.
  • Activate R integration in SAC
    • Configure R server: Specify the R server in SAC administration under System Configuration (either own server or the environment provided by SAP).
    • Create R scripts: In a story or an analytic application, the R package "collapsibleTree" can be loaded using the R widget function.
  • Create data lineage visualization with "collapsibleTree"
    • Pass data to R: Load the HANA table or view data into an R-compatible table structure via the R script in SAC.
    • Generate tree structure: Create an interactive tree representation with collapsibleTree::collapsibleTree(...) or a similar function.
    • Embed result: The generated graphic appears directly in the SAC story within the R widget and can be filtered and extended as needed.

Results and Benefits

  • Quick & cost-effective implementation: In this case, the customer already had SAP HANA and SAC licensed, so no additional investments were necessary.
  • Automation: Dependencies are read directly from SAP HANA Object Dependencies, eliminating the need for a separate ETL process or manual maintenance.
  • Interactive representation: Users can click through the tree structure and trace relationships between objects.

Figure 2: Representation of the data lineage within a SAC story.

Best Practices & Tips

  • Performance: For very large data volumes, it is advisable to perform aggregation or filtering in HANA beforehand and persist it.
  • Naming conventions: Consistent naming for tables and views makes the tree diagram easier to read.
  • Limitations: Complex procedures or dynamic SQL are not always fully recognized ‚Äì additional manual mapping may be necessary.
  • Visualization in R: For data lineage representation, we use the R package collapsibleTree, which is included in the SAP-provided R runtime environment (packages in the SAP R server environment). It can be used directly and free of charge in SAC without additional infrastructure. For extended visualization options, an own R server with additional packages can alternatively be connected.

 

Conclusion and Outlook

The visualization of data lineage in SAP Analytics Cloud using SAP HANA Object Dependencies and the R package "collapsibleTree" is a lean and cost-effective solution for companies that want to make their data origin traceable.

Thanks to the live data connection between HANA and SAC, no complicated interfaces or additional licenses are needed. With the out-of-the-box R integration and the interactive widgets of SAC, the origin and usage of tables can be traced in detail with just a few clicks.

The presented solution offers an efficient way, minimum in the short term, to provide developers and business units with more transparency about data flows. In the medium to long term, the use of specialized data governance solutions like Collibra or D-Quantum is recommended to centrally manage lineage, documentation, and responsibilities.

 

Questions, Feedback, and Contact

We are happy to answer questions and engage in further discussions ‚Äì either in the comments or through direct contact.

Do you need more information?

  • If further technical information is desired (e.g., configuration of the R server, scripting in SAC, performance optimization, manual mapping), let us know!
  • We are happy to dive deeper into the implementation details in a personal conversation.

We look forward to the exchange and are happy to provide further advice and implementation in the area of SAP Data & Analytics.

Authors:

Oliver Bulla (@OliverBulla), Senior Data Intelligence Consultant, specializing in SAP solutions, oliver.bulla@wavestone.com  

Christian Bantle (@christianbantle), Senior Data Intelligence Consultant, specializing in SAP solutions, christian.bantle@wavestone.com

(Disclaimer: This blog post is based on personal experiences and projects. The screenshots and examples shown are exemplary and may vary depending on the system landscape.)

entry.title: What's New in SAP Analytics Cloud Modeling Extensions & Integration QRC3 2025 Release
entry.content:
Purpose

Hello SAP Community Colleagues,

In QRC3 2025, we have an action-packed list of new features that have now been made available in the modeling area of SAP Analytics Cloud, within Business Data Cloud!

Overview

Learn more about these new features here:

  1. A new formula called WAVG (Weighted Average)

  2. First, Last and Average including unbooked data exception aggregation.

  3. Data Export API ‚Äì Delta Aggregation.

 

  1. New formula - WAVG  (Weighted Average)

A new formula has been introduced into the modeler, called WAVG.  This formula calculates the weighted average of a member, based on the value of the corresponding members assigned weight.  It can be used in standard and account models.

How Weighted Average is calculated:

 

Dimension 

Price

Stock

Price * Stock

Bread

2

10

20

Bread

3

20

60

Bread

4

30

120

Total

8

60

200

Table 1: Table containing product, price and stock values

 

Table 1 shows a simple list of products with various prices and stock amounts.

To calculate the Average Price, use the following calculation:

(2+3+4)/3 = 3

To calculate the Weighted Average Price, use the following calculation: (2*10) + (3*20) + (4*30) / (10 + 20 + 30 ) = 200 / 60 = 3.33

The weighted average calculation can provide a more accurate result, based on the given weight, compared to an average calculation.

Syntax:

WAVG([Measure] or [Account Member], [Assigned Weight], [Dimension 1], [Dimension 2]... [Dimension 10])

For example:

Figure 1: Sample WAVG Syntax

The above WAVG formula calculates the weighted average of [Price] using [Volume] as the assigned weight, for a given Date and Product.

Up to 10 dimensions can be used within the WAVG formula.

Note that input enablement on cells containing this calculated measure is available on leaf members only, which is the lowest level of the hierarchy.  It is planned to make input enablement available on other members in the future.

2.  First, Last and Average Exception Aggregation including Unbooked Data

You can now compute first, last and average exception aggregation including unbooked data using a single dimension on a base measure or base account with these three new exception aggregation values:

  • Average incl. Unbooked calculates the average of all aggregated values, including unbooked values.
  • First incl. Unbooked shows the first (oldest) value in the selected period, including unbooked values.
  • Last incl. Unbooked shows the last (most recent) value in the selected period, including unbooked values.

Figure 2: New exception aggregations in modeler

These new exception aggregations are supported in the standard and account model and can help to provide more accurate results on aggregated data.

Average including unbooked exception aggregation example:

Figure 3: Illustration on how Average incl. Unbooked now considers all months in period, instead of just months containing booked values

In the above example, an Average incl. Unbooked exception aggregation is applied to a base measure.  The total in Q1 is 100, in Q2 is 200, in Q3 is 300 and in Q4 is 400.

When booked values are only considered, the average is the sum of these values, divided by the number of booked entries, i.e. (100+200+300+400)/4 months=250.

When considering unbooked data, a more accurate average exception aggregation can now be calculated. 

i.e. (100+200+300+400)/12 months = 83.33

First including unbooked exception aggregation example:

Figure 4: Illustration on how First incl. Unbooked now considers all months in period, instead of just months containing booked values

Figure 4 shows an example of how First Incl. Unbooked exception aggregation now considers unbooked values in the first period, compared to when using First exception aggregation, that defaults to booked values.  Should this example show an entry for February, the top level of the hierarchy will still show unbooked values, as January is now considered within the formula even though it contains no data.  This provides a more accurate First exception aggregation result of entries for a given period. 

Figure 5: Illustration on how Last incl. Unbooked now considers unbooked values for a given period

Figure 5 shows how Last incl. Unbooked exception aggregation compares to Last exception aggregation.  Last exception aggregation contains 400 for October.  As this is the last period that contains booked values, results are seen at the top level of the hierarchy.  In contrast, Last incl. Unbooked also contains 400 for October, however, the last period is December, which contains an unbooked value.  This unbooked value is therefore seen at the top level of the hierarchy for that period, providing a more accurate result for the Last aggregation.

3.  Data Export API ‚Äì Fact Data Delta Aggregation

The Data Export API has been extended to support the export of aggregated delta of fact data, using a new ‚ÄòFactDataAggregation‚Äò endpoint. 

This means that changed fact data can now be aggregated and then exported, compared to exporting all changed fact data.  This feature compliments how S/4 consumes aggregated fact data.

Modelers can also access this feature within the API Subcriptions tab in their model.

Figure 6: Fact Data Delta Aggregation entity set within the Create Subscriptions area of the model

An example of how Delta Aggregation works:

Account

Product

Sales

Account1

Water

100

Account1

Juice

150

Account2

Water

200

Account2

Juice

150

Table 2: Accounts 1 & 2 contains Products and Sales.

Table 2 shows Account1 & Account2 contains 2 products at various sales values.

Account

Sales

Account1

250

Account2

350

Table 3: Aggregated values of Account1 & Account2

Let‚Äôs modify the sales values for both accounts:

Account

Product

Sales

Account1

Water

110

Account1

Juice

80

Account2

Water

75

Table 4: Sales values have changed, reflecting changed fact data.

The sales value for Water in Account1 has been change from 100 to 110.

The sales value for Juice in Account1 has been change from 150 to 80.

The sales value for Water in Account2 has been change from 200 to 75.

There is no change for Juice in Account2.

The aggregated fact data values are therefore calculated as follows:

Account

Sales

Account1

((110 - 100) + (80 - 150)) = -60

Account2

((75-200) + (150 ‚Äì 150)) = -125

Table 5: How the aggregated values are calculated

These are the values that will be exported using the ‚ÄòFactDataAggregation‚Äò endpoint or by using the Fact Data Delta Aggregation entity set in the API Subscriptions section of the model.

Conclusion

In summary, the following new features and updates have been introduced to the Modeling Extensions and Integration areas of SAP Analytics Cloud, within Business Data Cloud, as part of QRC3 2025 release.

  1. A new formula, called WAVG, calculates the weighted average of a member, based on the value of the corresponding members assigned weight. 
  2. Three new exception aggregations can be applied to base measures and base accounts. 
    • First incl. Unbooked shows the first (oldest) value in the selected period, including unbooked values.
    • Last incl. Unbooked shows the last (newest) value in the selected period, including unbooked values.
    • Average incl. Unbooked calculates the average of all aggregated values, including unbooked values.
  3. The Data Export API has been extended to support the export of aggregated delta of fact data using a new ‚ÄòFactDataAggregation‚Äò endpoint.  Modelers can also use the new Fata Data Delta Aggregation entity set name in the API Subscriptions tab of the model.

If you have any questions, feel free to comment below or post a question to our SAP Analytics Cloud Questions & Answers forum.

See this SAP Knowledge Base Article if you‚Äôd like to learn more about FastTrack and Quarterly Release Cycle releases.

For further information, visit our SAP Analytics Cloud Community pages to find more product information, best practices, and more. 

To find out more about QRC release dates, see SAP Analytics Cloud tenants on Quarterly Release Cycle (QRC) updates in 2025.

Check out our SAP Road Map Explorer to see more upcoming features of SAP Analytics Cloud.

Thanks for reading!

entry.title: Marla Alschweiki
entry.content:
Marla

  • Germany
  • SAP Mentor since 2025
  • Follow Marla on LinkedIn

In Marla's own words: "I am a curious SAP Data Analytics & AI Developer with a strong focus on Business Intelligence, Embedded Analytics, and AI-driven development. Over the past eight years, I've worked across the SAP ecosystem from S/4HANA and SAP BW to SAP Analytics Cloud and Fiori/UI5, where I've helped design and implement clean, scalable solutions that bridge backend data architecture with user-friendly interfaces.

I specialize in building modular Virtual Data Models using CDS Views, aligned with SAP‚Äôs clean core strategy.

I'm especially excited about the evolving landscape of SAP Business AI and its potential to transform how enterprises operate from predictive analytics and intelligent process automation to personalized user experiences.

I'm a strong believer in continuous learning, open knowledge-sharing, and the power of community. Whether through mentorship, collaboration, blogs, or workshops, I actively seek out opportunities to grow, uplift others, and create spaces where everyone feels empowered to learn, contribute, and thrive."

Topics of interest: SAP Data Analytics, SAP Business AI, Embedded Analytics, SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Fiori/UI5

Marla, what inspired you to become an SAP Mentor?

Becoming a mentor is my way of giving back to the SAP community that‚Äôs played such a big role in my journey. I truly believe that knowledge grows when it‚Äôs shared, and I want to help others find clarity and confidence in this fast-moving field. With my background in product development, I can help approach problems with a critical eye and a practical mindset to build SAP solutions that truly address real-world needs and push innovation forward.

What advice would like to share with other SAP community members?

Stay curious and don‚Äôt be afraid to ask questions, no matter how simple they seem. SAP is a vast ecosystem, and nobody knows everything. Collaboration and continuous learning are key. Also, share your experiences! Whether it‚Äôs a small tip, a lesson learned, or a project success, your voice might be exactly what someone else needs to hear.

entry.title: Sneak Peek in to SAP Analytics Cloud release for Q3 2025
entry.content:
We have a very special AI focused release coming your way this quarter. In this blog we give you a sneak peek into our Top 5 features in SAP Analytics Cloud for QRC3 2025. A full list of what is coming can be found on our Roadmap Explorer.  Let's dive in!

AI-assisted advanced formula generation

This quarter we bring you a number of exciting new AI-assisted features and we will start by looking at AI-assisted advanced formula generation. Within the advanced formula editor this feature utilizes generative AI to create advanced formula script logic from natural language comments, making the process of developing data actions easier, quicker, and more efficient.

This feature can also generate descriptions of existing advanced formulas generated automatically in natural language, reducing time and complexity associated with creating in-line script documentation.

 

AI-assisted chart summary

Continuing with AI, next up we have the new AI-Assisted Chart Summary, which leverages generative AI to automatically generate concise, human-readable summaries of SAP Analytics Cloud charts embedded in your PowerPoint presentations. Whether you're preparing for a meeting or sharing insights with stakeholders, this feature helps you communicate key takeaways faster and more clearly.

 

 

AI-assisted commenting

Our third AI-assisted feature enables users to streamline efforts to summarize, translate, and interpret comments with the table and comment widget. This includes shortening and simplifying long-form commentary into highlights, summarizing data point comment threads and aggregating data point comments from descendant cells. These features will also translate this summarization and aggregation to the user‚Äôs language specified in their profile. When authoring a new comment, the user will have the ability to rephrase comments

 

Home Page renewal

This release introduces a new and improved home page for SAP Analytics Cloud users. New cards options, alongside existing ones, offer quick access to relevant tools, tasks, resources, and insights. They are available for users to quickly and easily personalize their home screen layout and features with minimal effort, further empowering them to create a tailored and efficient user experience. The new home screen aims to streamline workflows, increase productivity, and foster a stronger association with innovation and improved usability for SAP Analytics Cloud users.

Existing cards remain supported like data change insight, calendar tasks, recent files, and featured files, while new cards become available like just ask, on boarding, quick action, resources, and many more.

 

 

Optimized table experience

Inspired by numerous requests from our influence portal, this quarter we introduce a new optimized table experience.

The optimized table experience provides interface consistency with chart widgets and includes all features of classic tables. Additional functionality includes undo/redo options, mobile compatibility, expanded tooltip settings, improved data synchronization, and a new intuitive builder panel designed for customizing layouts, assigning dimensions, adding calculations, and filtering data. As this is a wide topic it covers 6 new innovations on the Roadmap explorer listed below:

  • Blending for a table with support of sort, rank, totals, and custom order
  • New builder panel
  • Option to turn on and off the Thresholds tooltip when hovering over a data cell in a table
  • New client calculations panel
  • New member selector
  • Sort and Rank enhancements

 

There are plenty more exciting deliverables coming your way this quarter and we will be taking a deeper dive into these items in our What‚Äôs New video and blog series so stay tuned. For a full list of all features coming in QRC3 2025 for SAP Analytics Cloud check out the Roadmap Explorer  and the What's New Viewer

Want to experience new and existing features for yourself? Take the leap and start your journey towards making data-driven decisions with confidence by signing up for a free trial, today.

entry.title: New: Value Analytics for SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
Upon the release of the Q2 2025 SAP Analytics Cloud Content and SAP Datasphere Content package, a new page has been added to the SAP Value Analytics for Procurement story that is entirely dedicated towards SAP Fieldglass KPIs. This is the first of many updates to the tool that will expand its functionality far beyond SAP Ariba Procurement, allowing companies to analyze spend at a wider visibility than ever before.

The new page in SAP Value Analytics for Procurement provides a big picture summary of SAP Fieldglass spend categories. Just like the other stories, users are presented with a clean and simplified view of data from select KPIs. Companies that choose to operationalize this new page may easily gain insights on their SAP Fieldglass data, including:

  • The influence of workforce management efficiency on overall revenue
  • Costs incurred by ensuring projects & hiring processes stay compliant
  • The financial impact of maintaining a quality workforce

If providing users with a way to further operationalize SAP Fieldglass data in a comprehensive analysis of spend piques your interest, please continue reading for more information on how to activate the new SAP Fieldglass page in SAP Value Analytics for Procurement.

1. SAP Analytics Cloud - Strategic Spend Overview

After opening the SAP Value Analytics for Procurement story in SAP Analytics Cloud, navigate to the page entitled ‚ÄúFieldglass‚Äù. Along with the title, the top module contains a summary of spend related to high-value KPIs in SAP Fieldglass. A dimension module with a "Date Range" filtering option appears below the title module, followed by three data visualization modules, entitled ‚ÄúCost Savings‚Äù, ‚ÄúCompliance‚Äù, and ‚ÄúProcess Improvement‚Äù to represent the major categories of Fieldglass Transactions.

SAP Fieldglass page view in SAP Analytics Cloud

2. SAP Datasphere Integration for SAP Value Analytics for Procurement

Initiating the activation of the SAP Fieldglass page requires some manual configuration. After the necessary reports are built in Fieldglass, the user must download them in CSV format and upload them into SAP Datasphere. All other relevant objects can be found in the SAP_CONTENT space.

As of Q2 2025, the images below are the most updated views of the integration architecture and the SAP Datasphere objects included in the SAP Value Analytics for Procurement package.

Integration architecture (updated to include SAP Fieldglass assets)

SAP Datasphere objects view (updated to Include SAP Fieldglass objects)

As a reminder, the following naming conventions have been used:
SM -> Supplier Management
SC -> Sourcing & Contracts
BI -> Buying & Invoicing
FG -> Fieldglass

The data modeling for the SAP Fieldglass page follows the layered approach of content development in SAP Datasphere. Here, the set up for SAP Fieldglass Project analysis is used as the example, the photo below describing the direction of the model layers:

SAP Fieldglass data model workflow

The Integration Layer (IL) contains the local table SAP Fieldglass: Project (LT) (SAP_Fieldglass_SRC_Project_MA), which was created in a manual file upload, as mentioned previously. In addition, this layer also includes the abstracting view, SAP Fieldglass: Project (IL) (SAP_PROC_FG_IL_Project), which adds data specific to the realm.

The Harmonization Layer (HL), SAP Fieldglass: Project (HL) (SAP_PROC_FG_HL_ProjectSQL), acts as the Fact View that combines Fieldglass project data with the Date Grid view.

Finally, the Reporting Layer (RL) uses the Analytic Model SAP Fieldglass: Project (RL) (SAP_PROC_FG_RL_Project) to define additional calculated measures and expose the data to the SAP Fieldglass page in SAP Analytics Cloud.

3. Content Documentation

Thank you for reading this SAP Community article!

To view the blog post on the original release of SAP Value Analytics for SAP Ariba Procurement in Q2 2024, please view ‚ÄòMaximize Value with Value Analytics for SAP Ariba‚Äô by @SimonKranig.

For further instructions on configuring SAP Value Analytics for Procurement, please view this discovery mission.

More details on the SAP Fieldglass content package for SAP Value Analytics for Procurement can be found on this SAP Help page.

Have questions and want to share with other users? Feel free to post a question in the community:
SAP Community > SAP Analytics Cloud
SAP Community > SAP Datasphere

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in July
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in July

Another month with two great new release deliveries ‚ú®
Learn more in my short top features video in July 2025 on YouTube üì∫
In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs.

 

 

My top features in July

 

Data Integration & Connectivity

Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) as Source for Your Replication Flow

After delivering SFTP as a target already in May this year, you can now also use SFTP connections as sources in replication flows to any supported target.

‚û°Ô∏è   More information:

  • Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) as Source for Your Replication Flow
  • Generic SFTP Connections

 

Transport Objects Between File Spaces

You can now export objects from and import objects to file spaces, meaning a space based on the embedded object store with file-based artifacts.

‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

Task Chains

New Layout Option in Task Chain Toolbar

The options in the task chain editor toolbar have been re-arranged and a new layout option was added. The new layout option allows you to rearrange the visual display of a task chain on the canvas, from top-to-bottom (the default), or left-to-right.

‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

Connection Type Generic HTTP

With the new connection type, you can connect to external systems and add tasks that are exposed by REST-based APIs to task chains. For this purpose, we have introduced the new API Tasks connection feature, which is supported only for Generic HTTP connections.

‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

Running API Tasks in a Task Chain

The generic HTTP connection is the prerequisite to provide the ability of running tasks in a task chain that use a REST-based API to access external systems.

‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

New Notification Task Object in Task Chains

SAP Datasphere now allows users to set up additional email notification within a task chain, in addition to the notification specified for completion of the entire task chain. Users drag the new Notification Task object to any point in the sequence of tasks run in a task chain and then specify the subject and message for this new email notification. These new notifications use the same recipient list as the email notification maintained at the task chain level.

‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

Self-Service Enhancements

Enable Multi-Availability Zones for SAP HANA Cloud

Use the Enable SAP HANA Multi-Availability Zones option on the Tenant Configuration page to create a synchronous replica of the main system on a system in a different region. The synchronous replica system has a high-availability setup that can take over processing when necessary.

‚û°Ô∏è   More information:

  • Configure the Size of Your SAP Datasphere Tenant
  • Creating and Configuring Your SAP Datasphere Tenant

 

Enabling of SAP HANA for SQL data warehousing on Your SAP Datasphere Tenant

Administrators can now create the mapping between their SAP Datasphere tenant and their SAP Business Technology Platform account to enable SAP HANA for SQL data warehousing themselves, rather than needing to raise a ticket. Both environments for Kyma and Cloud Foundry are supported and the same information as previously required for the ticket with Organization ID and Space ID is required to be able to do the instance mapping.

‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

 

 

Webinar Series: Architecting Your SAP BDC Journey ‚Äì From Data to Intelligence 

There was a great architecture webinar series about SAP Business Data Cloud and various architecture deep dive topics. Thanks to @Gaurish-Dessai, @PaulKurchina, @helmut_grimm and team.

 

Sessions

Speakers

Data Inspired ‚Äì Successful concepts for data-driven organizations

Paul Kurchina, Dr. Sebastian Wernicke, Helmut Grimm, Gaurish Dessai

Unleash your Data and AI with Irfan Khan and Timo Elliott

Paul Kurchina, Irfan Khan & Timo Elliott

Unpacking SAP Business Data Cloud for Enterprise Architects

Ralph Richter, Gaurish Dessai, Axel Meier, Amogh Umbarkar

Enterprise Architects guide on SAP BW Modernization

Jason Luo & Gaurish Dessai

Planning your Transition Paths to SAP Business Data Cloud

Naveen Dumpa & Jason Luo

SAP Business Data Cloud and Databricks ‚Äì Stronger Together

Michelle Wiktorsson, Qi Su & Habeebuddin Mohammad

SAP Business Data Cloud & Databricks in Action with Demos

Michelle Wiktorsson, Gaurish Dessai, Rithivika Acharya & Peter Schmidt

SAP BDC Series Wrap up ‚Äì Insights, Learnings, and the Road Ahead

Paul Kurchina, Ralph Richter, Gaurish Desai, Prakash Nanduri & Timo Elliott

Find the session details, slides and recordings here
‚û°Ô∏è   Recordings and Slides from webinar series 'Architecting Your SAP Business Data Cloud Journey'

 

Learning Update

The number of learning opportunities are constantly growing and our colleagues in the learning department have delivered the next milestone with a new instructor-led class about SAP Business Data Cloud. Learn more in the blog from @MarkGreen 
‚û°Ô∏è   Learn SAP Business Data Cloud with our new instructor-led class

  • SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) Èñ¢ÈÄ£ÊÉÖÂ†± „Åæ„Å®„ÇÅ„Éñ„É≠„Ç∞
  • SAP Business Data Cloud: „Ç™„Éñ„Ç∏„Çß„ÇØ„Éà„Çπ„Éà„Ç¢ ÂÖ•ÈñÄÁ∑®

Find more information and related blog posts on the topic page for SAP Datasphere. You will find further product information on our Community with various subpages about Business Content, the SAP BW Bridge as well as content for Best Practices & Troubleshooting. Also check out the new support content for SAP Datasphere on SAP Help for troubleshooting and analysis guides, how-to guides, technical details, and more.

Find out how to unleash the power of your business data with SAP‚Äôs free learning content on SAP Datasphere. It‚Äôs designed to help you enrich your data projects, simplify the data landscape, and make the most out of your investment. Check out even more role-based learning resources and opportunities to get certified in one place on  SAP Learning site.

entry.title: How to Design Low-Fidelity Dashboards with the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit
entry.content:
Focus of this blog:

  • Intro
  • How the library is set up
  • How to get the library
  • How to use the library
  • How to work efficiently with the library
  • Essential Ressources

 

Intro

Effective dashboard design begins with user research. Gathering and understanding the necessary insights of your end-users' needs and requirements ensures high-quality experience. Jumping straight into creating high-fidelity mockups or even building dashboards directly in SAP Analytics Cloud Stories can create unnecessary distraction and slow down your design process.

üëâ  Learn how to build better dashboards here.

Instead, start with scribbles and rough sketches. Early in the process, low-fidelity mockups help you explore ideas quickly, collect feedback, and align on structure and meaningful insights before refining visual details.

That‚Äôs why we created the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit for Figma. It helps you transform your ideas seamlessly into digital low-fidelity designs.

The library offers basic layouts and provides components to help you design and iterate quickly, without distraction, ensuring you can focus on what matters: content, flow, and meaningful Insights. It helps you to speed up your design process, share clear ideas, review them with your team, and get feedback from stakeholders.

 

 

How the library is set up

The library consists of three pages, which allows for easy navigation and usage.

The first page, ‚Äúüìì Cover‚Äú, is a library overview that includes a cover, a version history and slides explaining the purpose and usage of the library.

Cover page of the SAP Analytics Cloud Schematics UI Kit

 

The second page, ‚Äú‚úèÔ∏è Analytical Pages‚Äù, provides dashboard templates. Depending on the purpose of your dashboard, you can choose to use different BI page types, or start with an empty page to design your dashboard from scratch.

Second page of the SAP Analytics Cloud Schematics UI Kit

 

The third page, ‚Äú‚úèÔ∏è Components‚Äù, contains all other assets: UI elements and controls, containers and different chart types available in SAP Analytics Cloud stories.

Third page of the SAP Analytics Cloud Schematics UI Kit

 

 

How to get the library

You can easily download the library from GitHub and import it into Figma.

üëâ  Navigate to the SAC Fiori Horizon Theme folder on GitHub.

Open the file "External_SAC_Dashboard_Schematics_UI_Kit.fig".

Overview of our GitHub folder structure

Click the Download button to save the file.

Placement of the download button on GitHub

Open the downloaded file in Figma. Choose a destination folder, and you're ready to go.

Overview of the import dialogs in Figma

 

 

How to use the library

We recommend publishing the library internally in your company's Figma space after importing the file to make use of Figma‚Äôs Library functionality. This means, that based on your settings, your direct team or your whole organization can access the library through the asset panel, enabling smooth collaboration and consistent usage across your design teams.

To publish a library, open the File Settings, navigate to ‚ÄúLibrary‚Äù and click on ‚ÄúPublish Library...‚Äù. Select the components you want to publish and specify who can access the library. Click on "Publish" and it's done.

Note: This option won't work if the file has been imported into your Drafts.

File options dropdown menu in Figma

 

Now you can add the SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit to your files through the libraries dialog and access all components directly from the assets panel.

If you don‚Äôt want to publish the library internally, you can simply copy and paste the components into your own design files or use them as local assets.

 

 

How to work efficiently with the library

To get started, we‚Äôve created a short introduction video that demonstrates how to build a dashboard using the library.

 

 

You can follow one of two possible workflows:

1. Start with an analytical page type

Open a new file and navigate to the assets panel. Drag an instance into your canvas, e.g. a "Monitoring Page".

In the design panel, you can see the different options you have for each instance. The "Monitoring Page" can use the visual type ‚ÄúPlaceholder‚Äù (default) or ‚ÄúContent‚Äù. Switching to ‚ÄúContent‚Äù will present basic charts.

Screenshot of the "Monitoring Page" with the "Visual Type" option set to "Placeholder".

 

Most components are nested within each other. This means you can simply select individual parts of an instance to get additional options in the design panel. This makes it easy to adjust the layout to fit your specific needs.

Screenshot of the "Sticky Header" instance in Figma, with its editable options visible in the design panel.

 

 

2. Start from scratch

Open a new file and either create a new frame or navigate to the assets panel to drag an "Empty Page" into your canvas. If you use the "Empty Page", you can detach the instance to freely use and customize the frame.

Screenshot of the "Empty Page" in Figma with the context menu open and the cursor hovering over the "Detach instance" option.

 

Browse or search for the containers you want to use, e.g. a header and multiple panels or cards, and drag them into your frame.

Screenshot of a new dashboard layout in Figma with one panel selected, showing its editable options in the design panel.

 

Set "Visual Type" to ‚ÄúContent‚Äù to show charts.

Screenshot of a dashboard with the "Visual Type" menu open and the cursor hovering over the "Content" option.

 

 

 

Feel free to share any feedback, ideas, questions, or requests regarding our SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit in the comments below.

And check out our Dashboard Design Best-Practices blog series that was created to assist you in designing and building meaningful dashboards with SAP Analytics Cloud.

 

Essential Ressources

SAP Analytics Cloud Dashboard Schematics UI Kit 

SAC Fiori Horizon Theme folder on GitHub

"Build Better Dashboards" - Process

Dashboard Design Best-Practices
